did.abstract: Collection illustrates establishment and years of activities of the Association of Polish Priests of Connecticut (APPC). The association was initially established under Polish name Zjednoczenie Kaplanow Polskich in 1915. The main mission of the association was to establish religious association of clergy who shared common ethnic heritage. The association represented interest of Polish clergy within the hierarchy of the Catholic Church which was almost exclusively run by clergy of the Irish heritage. The APPC was instrumental in organizing celebration of the Millennium of Polish Christianity in 1966, which was a hallmark of public manifestation of religious and cultural links between Polish Americans and the country of their forefathers. The association made numerous financial contributions to the Catholic Church in Poland and sponsored major book publication - a biography of Monsignor Bojnowski. In February of 1991 the association became an affiliate member of a national organization - the Polish American Priests Association which was established in San Antonio, Texas.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Priests from Connecticut Polish catholic parishes in Connecticut formed Association of Polish Priests of Connecticut initially under the Polish name Zjednoczenie Polskich Kaplanow in 1915. For over thirty years Rev. John J. Pitrus led the association. In the 1960s the organization started evolving towards more formal structure and the first Constitution was approved in 1967. It listed its goals as promotion and effective communication among priests of Polish origin. It provided priests with ways to find solutions to common problems of ethnic parishes and Catholics of Polish origin. The association promoted religious, cultural and social development of parishioners of Polish origin. Priests of Polish origin were looking for ways to find support and solutions to the problems of ethnic parishes and yet the catholic hierarchy was not openly support ethnic parishes. The hierarchy within the catholic church was mostly Irish and priests were of non-Irish origin. It was not easy to get promoted and receive help from the church administration. Therefore the Association of Polish Priests in Connecticut was a medium to find common ground to problems and their solutions and also provided social network for ethnic priests. The celebration of the Millennium of Polish Christianity in 1966 was the first state wide manifestation of strong religious and cultural roots of Polish American catholics with Poland. Several years later, in 1969, the association celebrated the 50th anniversary of Poland's independence and during the same year they invited Cardianl Karol Wojtyla of Cracow to Connecticut, who later become Pope John Paul II. In 1991 the APPC celebrated the 150th anniversary of the oldest Polish parish in Connecticut, the Saint Stanislaus church in Meriden. The following years brought more anniversaries and reasons for celebration and displaying unity among Polish and Polish American clergy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p: Material in the collection partially illustrates the history and evolution of the association. The first bound volume of minutes, written in Polish, is dated from 1946 till 1971. Additional minutes are arranged by date together with correspondence; other documents related to major events and projects organized by the Association are also arranged by date. Material related to significant events like Poland's Millennium of Christianity is arranged separately. Collection also includes copy of a constitution, mailing lists, sermons, a typescript of publication related to the history of the association entitled "An Interpretive History" by Rev. T. Mierzwinski (1971, 45 pp.), and several photo albums from various events. Material is arranged in 3 series: Series I: Minutes and correspondence, Series II: Poland's Millennium of Christianity and other anniversaries, Series III: History, constitution and activities.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
